ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: or a poor man in the dust;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: or to a destitute lying in dust;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: and downtrodden destitute person, (so that he would be of)
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Or of a homeless needy person!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Or to a Miskin cleaving to dust.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Or to the poor man lying in the dust.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: or a needy man in misery;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Or some poor wretch in misery,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: or some needy person in distress,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Or a poor man cleaving to the dust.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: or a needy man in desolation,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Or to the indigent (down) in the dust.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Or to a Miskin (poor) afflicted with misery.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: or to a needy person in distress;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Or a destitute in the dust.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Or a needy person in misery
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [90:16] or a needy person in misery (matraba: [literally means] ‘clinging to the dust [turāb]’ because of his poverty; a variant reading has two verbal nouns in place of the two verbs [fakka, ‘he freed’, and at‘ama, ‘he fed’], the first being in a genitive construction, fakku raqabatin, ‘the freeing of a slave’, and the second with nunation, it‘āmun, ‘to give food’, in which case there is an implied iqtihāmu before al-‘aqaba, of which the said reading becomes the explication);
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: Or some poor wretch in misery) and who has nothing,
